definitions: high-pitched sound made by forcing breath through pursed lips or narrow opening
method of signaling or communicating through melodic sounds without words
examples: The whistling from the teakettle signaled that water was ready
His cheerful whistling echoed through the empty hallway
The shepherd used whistling to direct his dogs across the field
Their secret whistling code helped them communicate during class

definitions: the smallest part or particle imaginable of something
examples: She doesn't care one whit about his opinion
There wasn't a whit of evidence to support the claim

definitions: the achromatic color of maximum lightness opposite to black
person belonging to a light-skinned ethnic group
transparent albumen surrounding the yolk of an egg
examples: The white of fresh snow covered the landscape
She painted the walls white to brighten the room
The neighborhood's demographic shifted from predominantly white to diverse
Census forms often categorize people as white or non-white
Separate the egg whites from the yolks carefully
The recipe calls for three egg whites beaten until stiff

definitions: silvery food fish found in cold northern lakes and rivers
examples: The restaurant specializes in smoked whitefish from Lake Superior
Commercial whitefish fishing supports many Great Lakes communities

definitions: small white or yellowish bump on skin caused by clogged pore
examples: The teenager worried about the whitehead on her forehead
Proper cleansing helps prevent whiteheads from forming

definitions: process of making something whiter or paler in color
examples: Teeth whitening has become a popular cosmetic procedure
The whitening of her hair happened gradually with age

definitions: white liquid mixture of lime or chalk used for painting walls
deliberate attempt to conceal unpleasant facts about someone or something
examples: They applied whitewash to the barn walls every spring
The old fence needed a fresh coat of whitewash
The report was dismissed as a whitewash of government failures
Critics called the investigation a complete whitewash

definitions: fast-flowing turbulent water in river rapids appearing white from foam
examples: The whitewater rafting expedition challenged even experienced paddlers
They navigated through dangerous whitewater below the falls

definitions: small silvery food fish related to cod found in European waters
finely powdered chalk used as pigment or polish
examples: Fresh whiting sells quickly at the fish market
The recipe called for pan-fried whiting with lemon
Artists mixed whiting with oil to create white paint
Jewelers use whiting to polish silver pieces

definitions: person who is extremely clever or skilled at something
sound of something moving very fast through air
examples: She's a whiz at solving complex mathematical problems
The computer whiz fixed our network in minutes
The whiz of bullets passed overhead during battle
I heard the whiz of the arrow before it struck

definitions: detective story or play about solving a crime or murder
examples: Agatha Christie wrote some of the best whodunits ever published
The whodunit kept readers guessing until the final chapter

definitions: thing that is complete in itself as a unity
examples: The whole is greater than the sum of its parts
We need to consider the problem as a whole

definitions: selling of goods in large quantities to retailers rather than consumers
examples: The company switched from retail to wholesale distribution
Wholesale prices are typically lower than retail prices

definitions: person or company that sells goods in large quantities to retailers
examples: The wholesaler supplies products to dozens of local stores
Food wholesalers deliver to restaurants throughout the region

definitions: loud cry or shout expressing excitement, joy, or triumph
examples: The children let out whoops of delight at the playground
His whoop of victory echoed across the stadium

definitions: something that is extremely or unusually large
outrageous or blatant lie told to deceive
examples: He caught a whopper of a fish on his first cast
That storm was a real whopper with record rainfall
She told a whopper about why she missed the meeting
His excuse was such a whopper nobody believed it

definitions: person who engages in sexual activity for payment
examples: Historical novels often depicted whores in port cities
The term whore carries significant social stigma

definitions: pattern of spirals or concentric circles in fingerprints, shells, or plants
examples: The detective examined the whorl pattern in the fingerprint
Each shell displayed a unique whorl of growth lines

definitions: cord or strand of fibers that draws fuel to flame in candles or lamps
examples: The candle wick needs trimming to prevent smoking
Oil lamps use a cotton wick to maintain the flame

definitions: pliable twigs or branches woven together to make furniture or baskets
examples: The patio furniture was made from weather-resistant wicker
She carried fresh bread in a wicker basket

definitions: set of three wooden posts in cricket that batsman defends
small door or gate especially one beside or within larger one
examples: The bowler knocked down the wicket with a fast delivery
He scored fifty runs before losing his wicket
Visitors entered through the wicket in the castle gate
The ticket office had a small wicket for transactions

definitions: act or process of making something broader or more extensive
examples: The widening of the highway will reduce traffic congestion
There's been a widening gap between rich and poor

definitions: small gadget or mechanical device especially one whose name is unknown
component of graphical user interface that displays information or provides interaction
examples: The factory produces thousands of plastic widgets daily
This widget controls the temperature settings
Add weather widgets to your phone's home screen
The dashboard widget shows real-time analytics

definitions: woman whose spouse has died and who has not remarried
examples: The widow received condolences from the entire community
She became a widow at the young age of thirty

definitions: man whose spouse has died and who has not remarried
examples: The widower struggled to raise three children alone
He remained a widower for the rest of his life

definitions: state or period of being a widow or widower after spouse's death
examples: She faced the challenges of widowhood with remarkable strength
His widowhood lasted only two years before remarrying

definitions: measurement or extent of something from side to side
examples: The width of the room is twelve feet exactly
Measure the width before ordering new curtains

definitions: smoked sausage similar to frankfurter often served in a bun
examples: The children roasted wieners over the campfire
He ordered a wiener with mustard from the vendor

definitions: married woman considered in relation to her spouse
examples: His wife manages the family's financial investments
They celebrated their wife and husband's golden anniversary

definitions: covering for the head made of real or artificial hair
examples: The actor wore a blonde wig for the role
Cancer patients often choose wigs during chemotherapy

definitions: quick short movement from side to side or up and down
examples: The puppy's tail wiggle showed its excitement
There's a slight wiggle in the loose tooth

definitions: dome-shaped dwelling used by some Native American peoples made of poles and bark or hides
examples: The museum displayed a reconstructed wigwam from the Algonquian peoples
Children learned about wigwam construction in history class

definitions: natural environment not cultivated or domesticated by humans
examples: They ventured deep into the wild for their expedition
Animals thrive better in the wild than captivity

definitions: small or medium-sized undomesticated cat living in the wild
risky or unsafe business venture especially unauthorized oil drilling
examples: The wildcat stalked its prey through the undergrowth
European wildcats are larger than domestic cats
The wildcat oil operation struck a massive deposit
Investors lost money on wildcat drilling schemes

definitions: large dark antelope with curved horns native to African grasslands also called gnu
examples: Millions of wildebeest migrate across the Serengeti annually
The wildebeest crossed the river despite lurking crocodiles

definitions: large destructive fire that spreads quickly over woodland or brush
examples: The wildfire consumed thousands of acres of forest
Climate change has increased the frequency of wildfires

definitions: flower of a plant that grows naturally without being deliberately planted
examples: The meadow bloomed with colorful wildflowers in spring
She pressed wildflowers between the pages of books

definitions: birds that are hunted as game especially ducks and geese
examples: Hunters need permits to shoot wildfowl during season
The wetlands provide habitat for migrating wildfowl

definitions: animals and plants living in natural conditions undomesticated by humans
examples: The national park protects endangered wildlife species
Urban development threatens local wildlife habitats

definitions: devious or cunning stratagem employed to manipulate or deceive
examples: She used her wiles to convince him to invest
The fox employed various wiles to escape hunters

definitions: legal document declaring person's wishes regarding disposal of property after death
faculty by which person decides on and initiates action through determination
examples: Her will left the estate to her three children
The lawyer read the will to the assembled family
His iron will helped him overcome numerous obstacles
She succeeded through sheer force of will

definitions: tree or shrub with narrow leaves and flexible branches typically growing near water
examples: The weeping willow draped its branches over the pond
Cricket bats are traditionally made from willow wood

definitions: control deliberately exerted to do something or restrain one's impulses
examples: Quitting smoking requires tremendous willpower and commitment
Her willpower helped resist the tempting dessert

definitions: weak and cowardly person lacking confidence or determination
examples: Don't be such a wimp about getting the injection
His teammates called him a wimp for avoiding contact

definitions: successful result in a contest, conflict, or competition
examples: The team celebrated their first win of the season
Her win at the championship surprised many critics

definitions: hauling or lifting device consisting of rope wound around rotating drum
examples: They used a winch to pull the boat onto the trailer
The electric winch lifted heavy equipment to the roof

definitions: natural movement of air especially strong enough to be felt
power of breathing especially as needed for physical exertion
examples: The wind knocked over several trees during the storm
Sailors depend on wind to power their vessels
The runner got his second wind after ten miles
The punch knocked the wind out of him

definitions: device or mechanism used for winding something such as a clock or thread
examples: The watch winder keeps automatic watches running when not worn
She used a bobbin winder to prepare thread for sewing

definitions: large amount of money or other benefit received unexpectedly
examples: The lottery win was an incredible windfall for the family
The company received a windfall from the tax changes

definitions: course or path that follows a twisting or spiral route
examples: The winding of the mountain road made driving dangerous
We followed the winding through the ancient maze
